content.statement: vascular:venous:dvd-004-iliac-stenting is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Venous that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding vascular:venous:dvd-004-iliac-stenting helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of vascular:venous:dvd-004-iliac-stenting include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of vascular:venous:dvd-004-iliac-stenting.

may_thurner_syndrome.description: Compression of left common iliac vein by right common iliac artery

post_thrombotic_syndrome.description: Chronic iliofemoral obstruction from organized thrombus

pre_procedure_evaluation: CT or MR venography for anatomic planning

access: Popliteal vein (preferred - straight path to iliocaval)
ivus_assessment: Measure cross-sectional area at stenosis and normal segments
Identify webs, synechiae, and chronic thrombus
stent_deployment: Size stent to normal adjacent vein (typically 14-24mm)
Deploy from mid-common femoral vein to beyond obstruction
Overlap stents by 1-2cm if multiple needed
Extend to IVC if lesion at confluence
post_procedure: Duplex surveillance at 1, 3, 6, 12 months, then annually for life of stent

stent_options.wallstent: Woven stainless steel, high radial force, significant shortening
stent_options.venovo: Nitinol, dedicated venous design, minimal shortening

complications: Contralateral iliac compression (if extending to IVC)
presentation: Chronic leg swelling worse with standing
Venous claudication (bursting leg pain with exercise)
diagnosis: IVUS at time of procedure (gold standard)
>50% cross-sectional area stenosis on IVUS is significant

definition.@value: An endovascular procedure using dedicated large-diameter venous stents to treat symptomatic iliofemoral venous outflow obstruction from May-Thurner syndrome, post-thrombotic syndrome, or extrinsic compression, guided by intravascular ultrasound to optimize sizing and deployment.

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Identify indications for iliac vein stenting
Describe the role of IVUS in iliac stenting
Apply appropriate post-stent anticoagulation and surveillance
clinical_pearls: IVUS is essential - venography underestimates stenosis by 30-50%
>50% cross-sectional area stenosis on IVUS is hemodynamically significant
May-Thurner has excellent outcomes; post-thrombotic is slightly lower
Size stents to normal adjacent vein, not the stenotic segment
Popliteal access provides the straightest path to iliocaval junction

medicalCode.description: Transcatheter placement of intravascular stent, iliac vein
Dilation of common iliac vein with intraluminal device
